images.alt: The homepage with a dark theme
Call to action and coming soon section

updates.personalNotes: My home page! I've always wanted to work with a dark UI, so I decided to go with a dark theme for my website. The hero section is the first thing you see when you visit the site, and I wanted it to be visually striking. The about me section is a brief introduction to who I am, and the call to action is a prompt for visitors to check out my projects. The coming soon section is a placeholder for future content.

images.alt: The project gallery and card effects

updates.personalNotes: I knew I wanted to have a project gallery on my website. In terms of design card, I was inspired by Pokemon trading cards which have a clear title in the upper left, a main image in the upper half, and text details in the lower half. I decided to go a bit further and have the cards tilt away from the cursor when hovered as well have a gliding shine effect.

I wish I had this idea for a build log earlier, because I spent some time trying to make the project cards from my gallery flip and grow to take up majority of the page while maintaing a cohesive UI. I ended up scrapping that idea and just making a simple details page with a header, a gallery of images, and a text section for the description. This is the initial skeleton.

summary: Updated project details page with initial design.

updates.description: Implemented the initial design for the project details page.
updates.personalNotes: My initial design was inspired by note taking apps like Notion where key information is isolated to its own container. I also wanted to try creating a glass effect for my cards on this page. This was a good start, but needed to be improved on.

updates.description: Included a way to access progress page.

images.alt: The home page with link to progress page

updates.personalNotes: I wanted to make the progress map clearly accessible without taking up space in the header. I decided to repeat what I had done with the project gallery link on the homepage.
Created the build log page and set up routing.

summary: Focused mainly on implementing the project detail page and adding more cohesive UI.

updates.personalNotes: I've added my updates as glass cards that appear from my most recent update to my first update. I also wanted to showcase the glass effect of my cards and add depth, so I added in a linear gradient to the background.

I wanted to make the project details page more cohesive as a whole by balancing my elements and utilizing depth. The glass effect of the cards is exemplified by the parallax effect of the gently moving cirlces in the background.

updates.description: Updated the homepage to have depth.

images.alt: The homepage with a linear gradient background
The homepage with a linear gradient background
The homepage with a linear gradient background (with hover effect triggered, but not finished)

updates.personalNotes: In an effort to improve the UI for my homepage, I've added in a gradient.

updates.description: Project gallery page now has linear gradient background.

images.alt: The project gallery with a linear gradient background
The project gallery with a linear gradient background

summary: Focused on rounding out homepage UI.

images.alt: The homepage with glass cards and new spacing
View projects, summary, and build log

updates.personalNotes: I've put the about me text inside of a glass card, made my "Explore My Projects" and "View My Build Log" look clickable, and added and about for the home page.

images.alt: The resume page with an embedded PDF

updates.personalNotes: This was something I'm glad I finally finished! After reviewing my resume and deciding on a final draft, I embedded it to my website.

images.alt: The project detail page with image carousel

updates.personalNotes: Proof that sometimes you just need to take a break! What I tried to implement after hours of coding, I was able to implement in a few minutes after taking a break.
I realized my meta tags weren't updating for the page.
I finally had some time to fix my filter!

summary: Fixed 404 routing issue caused by SPA + Github Pages.

updates.description: Fixed 404 routing issue caused by SPA + Github Pages
updates.personalNotes: This was something I wanted to fix for a hot minute. Github pages does not play friendly with routing for SPA, but by including a 404.html in public/ with some extration and transformations in my App.tsx, I was able to have direct routing with actual 404s re-routing to the home page.
